subSection.paragraph: A R T I C L E I N F O
Iboga

A B S T R A C T

Eight undescribed iboga alkaloids, polyneurines A H, were isolated from the bark of
Tabernaemontana polyneura
. The structures of these alkaloids were established by interpretation of the MS and NMR data, while the configurations were determined using GIAO NMR calculations and DP4+probability analysis, TDDFT-ECD method, or X-ray diffraction analysis. Polyneurine A possesses a γ -lactone unit embedded within the iboga skeleton, while polyneurines D and E incorporate a formylmethyl moiety at C-3 of the iboga skeleton. Biosynthetic pathways towards the formation of polyneurines A, C, D, and E were proposed.

The genus
Tabernaemontana (Apocynaceae)
has a broad distribution over the tropical and subtropical regions of the world, encompassing parts of America, Africa including Madagascar , Asia, Oceania, and Australia ( Leeuwenberg, 1991 ). Plants of this genus are used in Chinese, Ayurvedic and Thai traditional medicine for the treatment of dysentery, fever, and pain, as well as for the treatment of snakebites in Brazil ( Abubakar and Loh, 2016 ; Marinho et al., 2016 ). Previous studies on the chemical constituents of this genus have resulted in the discovery of many new alkaloids, particularly indole and bisindole alkaloids possessing structurally novel skeletons and useful biological activities ( Kam, 1999 ; Kam et al., 2004 ; Kam and Choo, 2006 ; Kam and Lim, 2008 ; Marinho et al., 2016 ; Nge et al., 2016a , 2016b ; Sim et al., 2016 , 2019 ; Van Beek et al., 1984 ).
Tabernaemontana polyneura (King & Gamble) D.J. Middleton
(basionym:
Ervatamia polyneura
) is endemic in Peninsular Malaysia ( Middleton, 2011 ). A preliminary phytochemical investigation of
T. polyneura
(sample collected at Genting Sempah, Selangor , Peninsular Malaysia ) was first reported by Clivio et al., in 1990. Since no further studies of this plant have been reported and in view of our interest in probing the variation of alkaloid content as a function of geographical location in this genus, we initiated a larger scale study of a sample collected in a different location (Fraser’ s Hill, Pahang , Peninsular Malaysia ), and herein report the results of the isolated compounds ( Fig. 1 ).

Polyneurine A ( 1 ) was obtained as a light orange oil, [α] D 25 44 ( c 0.2, CHCl 3 ). The UV spectrum showed absorption maxima at 226, 284, and 291 nm , indicating the presence of an indole chromophore, while the IR spectrum showed absorption bands at 3427 and 1756 cm 1 , suggesting the presence of NH and γ -lactone functions, respectively. The HRDARTMS data showed an [M + H] + peak at m/z 323.1761 corresponding to the molecular formula C 20 H 22 N 2 O 2 . The 1 H NMR data ( Table 1 ) showed the presence of an indolic NH ( δ H 9.59), four aromatic resonances ( δ H 7.10–7.49) due to an unsubstituted indole moiety, as well as an ethyl side chain ( δ H 1.03, t, J = 7.5 Hz, Me-18; δ H 1.80, dq, J = 14.5, 7.5 Hz, H-19a; δ H 1.98, dq, J =14.5, 7.5 Hz, H-19 b). The 13 C NMR data ( Table 2 ) showed a total of 20 carbon resonances comprising one methyl, six methylenes, six methines, one ester carbonyl, one tertiary carbon linked to an ester oxygen, two tertiary carbons bonded to indolic nitrogen, and three quaternary carbon atoms. The COSY data revealed the presence of NCH 2 CH 2 , CH 2 CHCH 2 , and CH 2 CH 3 partial structures, corresponding to N–C-5 C-6, C-15 C-14 C-17 and C-19 C-18, respectively ( Fig. 2 ). These structural features are reminiscent of the iboga skeleton, e.g., coronaridine ( 9 ) ( Santos et al., 2009 ), except for the absence of signals due to H-20 and the ester methyl in 1 . This is in agreement with the molecular formula of 1 , which differs from that of 9 by 16 mass units ( CH 3 +H). In addition, the 13 C NMR data of 1 displayed an upfield shift of the C-16 resonance from ca. δ C 55 in 9 to δ C 45.7 in 1 , whereas the signal of C-20 (usually observed at ca. δ C 40 as in 9 ) was significantly shifted downfield to δ C 88.1, likely due to being linked to an oxygen atom. These observations suggested the presence of a lactone bridge that connects C-16 and C-20 ( Fig. 1 ), which was confirmed by the three-bond correlations observed from H-17 to C OO, as well as from H-14 to C-16 and C- 20 in the HMBC spectrum ( Fig. 2 ). The relative configuration of 1 was deduced to resemble that of coronaridine ( 9 ) based on the NOE data ( Fig. 3 ). The NOEs observed for H-21/H-5 α and H-9/H-6 α suggested that H-5 α , H-6 α , and H-21 occupied the same face, whereas the NOEs observed for H-3b/H-5 β , H-6 β , H-17 β and H-3a/H-15 β indicated that these protons were cofacial. Similarly, H-17 α and H-15 α were assigned based on the NOE observed between H-17 α and H-15 α .

A search of the literature revealed that a compound similar to 1 was obtained as a by-product during a total synthesis of vinblastine ( Ishikawa et al., 2009 ). Compound 1 has similar 1 H and 13 C NMR, MS, and IR spectroscopic data compared to those of the synthetic compound ( 10 ) but showed opposite sign for the specific rotation ([α] D 25 44 for
1 vs
[α] D 22 +33 for 10 ), suggesting an enantiomeric relationship between 1 and 10 . In any case, the absolute configuration of 1 was further confirmed by TDDFT-ECD method. The experimental ECD spectrum of 1 showed high-amplitude negative Cotton effects at 220 and 245 nm and positive Cotton effects at 233 and 288 nm , which resemble the calculated ECD spectrum of 1 ( Fig. 4 ), leading to the assignment of the absolute configuration of 1 as (14 S , 16 S , 20 R , 21 R ). In addition, the experimental ECD data also matches with the experimental ECD data of voacangalactone ( 11 ), a 10-methoxy derivative of 1 ( Harada et al., 2012 ) and this provided further confirmation of the structure and absolute configuration of 1 . A plausible biosynthetic pathway to 1 from an iboga precursor, heyneanine ( 12 ), is shown in Fig. 5 . Generation of a secondary carbocation at C-19 followed by a 1,2-H shift provides a tertiary carbocation at C-20, which on nucleophilic attack by a water molecule leads to 13 . A subsequent intramolecular transesterification furnishes compound 1 .

Polyneurine B ( 2 ) was initially isolated as a colorless oil, [α] D 25 44 ( c 0.5, CHCl 3 ), and subsequently as colorless plates from CCl 4 /MeOH (mp 175–177 ο C). The UV spectrum showed absorption maxima at 217, 220, 285, and 292 nm , indicating the presence of an indole chromophore, while the IR spectrum showed absorption bands at 3258 and 1716 cm 1 , suggesting the presence of NH/OH and ester carbonyl functions, respectively. The HRESIMS data showed an [M + H] + peak at m/z 373.2139, which corresponds to the molecular formula, C 21 H 28 N 2 O 4 . The 1 H and 13 C NMR data ( Tables 1 and 2 ) of 2 were generally similar to those of 3-hydroxy-3,4- seco coronaridine ( 14 ) ( Clivio et al., 1990 ), suggesting that they share a similar basic skeleton. The 1 H NMR data of 2 showed the presence of an indolic NH ( δ H 8.55), four aromatic hydrogens ( δ H 7.07–7.46) and a methyl ester ( δ H 3.65), while the 13 C NMR data showed a total of 21 resonances, including the notable downfield shift of the C-3 methylene resonance to δ C 67.3 (which was commonly observed at ca. δ C 52 in 9 ), indicating a cleavage of the C-3 N-4 bond and substitution of an OH at C-3. The most pronounced difference in the NMR data between 2 and 14 was the presence of a hydroxyethyl group at C- 20 in 2 , in place of the ethyl side chain in 14 . This is consistent with the observed oxymethine resonance at δ C 72.0 in the 13 C NMR spectrum, as well as the signals due to a hydroxyethyl side chain ( δ H 1.39, d, J = 6.5 Hz, Me-18; δ H 3.86, qd, J = 6.5, 3.0 Hz, H-19) in the 1 H NMR spectrum. Analysis of the COSY data also revealed the presence of a CHCHCH 3 fragment in 2 ( Fig. 2 ), in place of the CHCH 2 CH 3 fragment in 14 , due to C-20 C-19 C-18. Attachment of the hydroxyethyl side chain at C-20 was further supported by the following three-bond correlations in the HMBC spectrum, viz., from H-19 ( δ H 3.86) to C-15 ( δ C 27.7) and C-21 ( δ C 53.1), as well as from H-18 ( δ H 1.39) to C-20 ( δ C 42.3) ( Fig. 2 ). The relative configurations at all the stereogenic centers in 2 , except for C-19, were readily determined via analysis of the NOE data ( Fig. 3 ). Since suitable crystals of 2 were obtained, an X-ray diffraction analysis was carried out, which confirms the structure and the absolute configuration of 2 as (14 R , 16 S , 19 R , 20 S , 21 S ) ( Fig. 6 ).

Polyneurine C ( 3 ) was isolated as a light yellowish oil, [α] D 25 28 ( c 0.2, CHCl 3 ). The UV spectrum showed absorption maxima at 223 and 286 nm , indicating the presence of an indole chromophore, while the IR spectrum showed absorption bands at 3374 and 1726 cm 1 , suggesting the presence of OH/NH and ester carbonyl functions, respectively. The HRESIMS data showed an [M + H] + peak at m/z 385.2130, corresponding to the molecular formula, C 22 H 28 N 2 O 4 . The 1 H NMR data ( Table 1 ) showed the presence of an indolic NH ( δ H 7.89), four aromatic resonances of an unsubstituted indole moiety ( δ H 7.10–7.47), a methyl ester ( δ H 3.72), and a hydroxyethyl side chain ( δ H 1.27, d, J = 6.4 Hz, Me-18; δ H 3.88, qd, J =6.4, 3.2 Hz, H-19). The 13 C NMR data ( Table 2 ) showed the presence of one methyl, five methylenes, nine methines, one methyl ester, one ester carbonyl, two tertiary carbons bonded to indolic NH, and three quaternary carbons, for a total of 22 carbon resonances. The 1 H and 13 C NMR data of 3 showed features typical of iboga alkaloids with some differences, viz., the presence of a hydroxymethyl linked to C-3 and a hydroxyethyl side chain attached to C-20. These observations were supported by the presence of the corresponding oxymethylene (C-3) and oxymethine resonances (C-19), at δ C 60.5 and 70.8, respectively. These assignments were also supported by the HMBC data which showed three-bond correlations from H-24 to C-14, H-15 and H-21 to C-19, and H-18 to C-20 ( Fig. 2 ). The relative configuration was determined via analysis of the NOE data ( Fig. 3 ) as well as from analysis of the vicinal coupling constants ( Table 1 ). The configuration at C-3 was determined to be S based on the NOEs observed between H-3 and H-5 β , H-6 β , H-17 β as well as between H-24 and H-15 β ( Fig. 3 ). The β -orientation of the hydroxyethyl side chain at C-20 was determined based on the H-15 α /H-20 NOE ( Fig. 3 ) as well as the observed J
15 α –20
coupling value of 11.0 Hz, which requires the H-20 α /H-15 α dihedral angle to be ~0 ◦ ( Nge et al., 2016a ). The 19 R configuration was assigned based on the chemical shifts of H-18 ( δ H 1.27), H-19 ( δ H 3.88), H-21 ( δ H 4.18), and C-21 resonance ( δ C 54.7), which correspond to those of the 19 R series of iboga alkaloids with a β -substituted hydroxyethyl side chain at C-20 ( Sim et al., 2016 ; Takayama et al., 1994 ; Wenkert et al., 1976 ). The 19 R configuration was further confirmed by the Gauge-Including Atomic Orbital (GIAO) NMR calculations and DP4+ probability analysis ( Grimblat et al., 2015 ). The experimental NMR data were compared with the calculated 1 H and 13 C NMR shifts of 3 and its C-19 epimer 3a , using DP4+ probability analysis. As shown in Fig. 7 , compound 3 with 19 R configuration showed DP4+probability score of 100% (based on all NMR data). Finally, the absolute configuration of 3 was established as (3 S , 14 R , 16 S , 19 R , 20 S , 21 S ) based on comparison of the experimental and calculated ECD spectra ( Fig. 4 ).

subSection.paragraph:
Polyneurine D ( 4 ) was isolated in minute amount as a light yellowish oil, [α] D 25 36 ( c 0.1, CHCl 3 ). The UV spectrum showed absorption maxima at 225, 285, and 293 nm , indicating the presence of an indole chromophore, while the IR spectrum showed absorption bands at 3376, 1725 and 1718 cm 1 , suggesting the presence of OH/NH, ester, and aldehyde carbonyl functionalities, respectively. The HRESIMS data showed an [M + H] + peak at m/z 397.2126, corresponding to the molecular formula, C 23 H 28 N 2 O 4 , which is 12 mass units higher than that of 3 . The 13 C NMR data ( Table 2 ) accounted for all 23 carbon resonances, including one methyl, five methylenes, nine methines, one methyl ester, one ester carbonyl, one formyl, two tertiary carbons bonded to indolic NH, and three quaternary carbons. The 1 H NMR data ( Table 1 ) showed some common features with that of 3 , viz., an indolic NH ( δ H 7.85), an unsubstituted indole ring ( δ H 7.11–7.47), a methyl ester ( δ H 3.73), and a hydroxyethyl side chain ( δ H 1.28, d, J =7.0 Hz, Me-18; δ H 3.89, qd, J = 7.0, 2.8 Hz, H-19). However, unlike 3 , a formylmethyl is attached at C- 3 in
4 in
place of the hydroxymethyl in 3 . This is evident from the presence of the aldehyde signal ( δ H 9.76; δ C 201.4) in 4 , as well as the upfield shifts observed for C-3 ( δ C 53.6 in
4 vs δ
C 60.5 in 3 ) and C-24 ( δ C 46.3 in
4 vs δ
C 62.0 in 3 ). Furthermore, the COSY data ( Fig. 2 ) revealed an extended spin system NCHCH 2 CHO, corresponding to the N-4 C-3 C-24 CHO partial structure. These observations were also consistent with the HMBC data which showed three-bond correlations from the formyl hydrogen to C-3 and from H-3 to the formyl carbon ( Fig. 2 ). The relative configuration at C-3 was deduced to be R based on the observed NOE interactions for H-24/H-15 β and H-3/H-5 β , H-17 β ( Fig. 3 ). The relative configurations of the remaining stereogenic centers were similar to those in 3 , based on comparison of the NOE as well as chemical shift data. Similar to 3 , the 19 R configuration was assigned based on the chemical shifts of H-18 ( δ H 1.28), H-19 ( δ H 3.89), H-21 ( δ H 4.14), and C-21 resonance ( δ C 55.0) ( vide supra ). In addition, the GIAO NMR calculations and DP4+ analysis supported 4 with 19 R configuration as the correct relative configuration, with 100% DP4+ probability (all data) ( Fig. 7 ). Finally, the absolute configuration of 4 was established as (3 R , 14 R , 16 S , 19 R , 20 S , 21 S ) based on comparison of the experimental and calculated ECD spectra ( Fig. 4 ).

Polyneurine E ( 5 ) was obtained in minute amount as a light orange oil, [α] D 25 29 ( c 0.1, CHCl 3 ). The UV spectrum of 5 showed typical indole absorption maxima at 227, 286, and 293 nm , while the IR spectrum showed absorption bands due to NH ( 3378 cm 1 ), ester ( 1726 cm 1 ), and aldehyde carbonyl ( 1717 cm 1 ) functions. The HRESIMS ([M +H] + m/z 381.2174) data established the molecular formula of 5 as C 23 H 28 N 2 O 3 , which is 16 mass units less than 4 , suggesting a deoxy derivative of 4 . The 1 H and 13 C NMR data ( Tables 1 and 2 ) of 5 showed similarities with those of 4 , such as the presence of a formyl group ( δ H 9.77; δ C 202.5), an indolic NH ( δ H 7.80), four aromatic hydrogens ( δ H 7.09–7.47), and a methyl ester group ( δ H 3.71; δ C 52.7, 175.4). The only notable difference in the 1 H and 13 C NMR data between 5 and 4 was the replacement of signals due to the hydroxyethyl side chain present in 4 with signals due to an ethyl side chain in 5 . This observation was also consistent with the presence of a fragment, CH 2 CHCH 2 CHCH 2 CH 3 , which corresponds to the C-17 C-14 C-15 C-20 C-19 C-18 partial structure ( Fig. 2 ). Ethyl side chain substitution at C-20 was also indicated from the HMBC data ( Fig. 2 ), which showed the following three-bond correlations, H-18/C-20, H-15/C-19, and H-19/C-21. Examination of the NOE data ( Fig. 3 ) of 5 showed that its relative configuration was similar to those of 3 and 4 . The absolute configuration of 5 was established as (3 R , 14 R , 16 S , 20 S , 21 S ) based on comparison of the experimental and calculated ECD spectra ( Fig. 4 ).

subSection.paragraph: A plausible biosynthetic pathway to 3 , 4 , and 5 from an iboga precursor, 3( S )-cyanocoronaridine ( 15 ) ( Kam et al., 2004 ) is shown in Fig. 8 . Hydrolysis of 15 followed by reduction leads to ervatamine G ( 16 ) ( Zhang et al., 2015 ). Subsequent formation of the enamine 17 , followed by an intermolecular enamine-formaldehyde reaction leads to the C-25 hydroxy intermediate, 18 . Finally, oxidation of 18 leads to 5 . Compounds 3 and 4 may have formed from a similar biosynthetic pathway with the hypothetical 19 R -hydroxy derivative of 3 ( S )-cyanocoronaridine 19 .

Polyneurine F ( 6 )
was initially obtained as a light yellowish oil, [α] D 25 43 ( c 0.4, CHCl 3 ), and subsequently as light yellowish block crystals from EtOH (mp 153–154 ◦ C). The UV spectrum showed absorption maxima at 223, 285, and 293 nm , which were characteristic of an indole chromophore, while the IR spectrum showed the presence of NH/OH ( 3331 cm 1 ), ester ( 1732 cm 1 ), and lactam ( 1657 cm 1 ) functions. The HRESIMS data ([M + H] + m/z 369.1817) established the molecular formula of 6 as C 21 H 24 N 2 O 4 . The 13 C NMR data ( Table 2 ) displayed a total of 21 carbon resonances, comprising six methylenes, seven methines, one methyl ester, one ester carbonyl, one amide carbonyl, two tertiary carbons linked to indolic NH, and three quaternary carbons
, in
agreement with the molecular formula. The 1 H NMR data ( Table 1 ) showed the presence of an indolic NH ( δ H 8.12), an unsubstituted indole moiety ( δ H 7.09–7.48), a methyl ester ( δ H 3.72), and a 1-hydroxyethyl side chain ( δ H 3.74, 3.81, H-18; δ H 1.64, 1.77, H-19). The 13 C NMR data showed the presence of an oxymethylene at δ C 60.2 and a methylene at δ C 37.5, which were attributed to C-18 and C-19, respectively from the HSQC and COSY data ( Fig. 2 ). The COSY data indicated the presence of a CH 2 CHCH 2 CHCH 2 CH 2 partial structure, which corresponds to C-17 C-14 C-15 C-20 C-19 C- 18 in 6 . This was further confirmed by the three-bond correlations from H-18 ( δ H 3.74 and 3.81) to C-20 ( δ C 30.6), and from H-20 ( δ H 2.05) to C-18 ( δ C 60.2) ( Fig. 2 ). In addition, the presence of an amide carbonyl at C-3 was in agreement with the three-bond correlations observed from H-5, H-15, H-17, and H-21 to C-3 ( δ C 176.3) ( Fig. 2 ). Additionally, the presence of the C-3 carbonyl has resulted in a noticeable anisotropic deshielding of H-5 β ( δ H 4.48) ( Nge et al
., 2016 a),
compared to δ H 3.1–3.4 for H-5 β in
1
,
3–5
. The NOE data ( Fig. 3 ) also showed that the relative configuration of 6 was similar to that of compounds 1–5 . Since suitable crystals were obtained, an X-ray diffraction analysis was also carried out which confirmed the structure and provided the absolute configuration of 6 (14 R , 16 S , 20 R , 21 S ) ( Fig. 9 ).

subSection.paragraph:
Polyneurine G ( 7 )
was isolated as an orange oil, [α] D 25 25 ( c 0.4, CHCl 3 ). The UV spectrum showed absorption maxima indicative of an indole chromophore at 225, 285, and 293 nm , while the IR spectrum showed the presence of NH/OH and ester groups at 3376 and
1728 cm
1 , respectively. The HRESIMS data ([M + H] + m/z 371.1984) established the molecular formula of 7 as C 21 H 26 N 2 O 4 . The 1 H NMR data ( Table 1 ) showed the presence of an indolic NH ( δ H 8.13), four aromatic hydrogens ( δ H 7.08–7.47), a methyl ester ( δ H 3.73), and a 1,2-disubstituted ethyl side chain ( δ H 3.61, 3.76, H-18; δ H 3.78, H-19). The 13 C NMR data ( Table 2 ) indicated 21 carbon resonances, comprising six methylenes, eight methines, one methyl ester, one ester carbonyl, two tertiary carbons linked to indolic NH, and three quaternary carbons. The COSY and HMBC data ( Fig. 2 ) led to the elucidation of the structure for the compound as the vicinally-dihydroxysubstituted coronaridine derivative (18,19-dihydroxycoronaridine). The oxymethylene and oxymethine resonances corresponding to the vicinally-dihydroxysubstituted C-18 C-19 were seen at δ C 65.8 and 75.5, respectively. A search of the literature revealed that this 2D structure was previously assigned to 18,19-dihydroxycoronaridine ( 20 ) ( Azoug et al., 1995 ), which does not possess identical 1 H and 13 C NMR data to those of 7 , suggesting 7 to be an epimer of 20 . Since the relative configurations at C-14, C-16, C-20, and C-21 were found to be identical to those of compounds 1–6 ( Fig. 3 ), the only stereochemical difference between compounds 7 and 20 must be at C-19. The stereochemistry at C-19 was assigned by comparing the 13 C NMR data of 7 and 20 with those of 19 R - and 19 S -heyneanine ( Takayama et al., 1994 ; Wenkert et al., 1976 ). In 7 , C- 15 and C-21 were observed at δ C 28.3 and δ C 54.9, respectively, which correspond to the corresponding carbon shifts in the 19 R -hydroxyiboga alkaloid series such as 19- epi -heyneanine (i.e., C-15 at ca. δ C 29; C-21 at ca. δ C 55). On the contrary, C-15 and C-21 of 20 were found at δ C 23.7 and δ C 59.2, respectively ( Azoug et al., 1995 ), which are consistent with those found in the 19 S -hydroxyiboga alkaloid series such as heyneanine. We can therefore deduce that compound 7 possesses an opposite relative configuration at C-19 (i.e., S ), compared to 20 with a 19 R configuration ( Azoug et al., 1995 ). The deduction was further confirmed by GIAO NMR calculations and DP4+ analysis. The experimental NMR data were compared with the calculated 1 H and 13 C NMR shifts of 7 and its C-19 epimer 7a using DP4+analysis. The DP4+results supported 7 with 19 S configuration as the correct relative configuration, with 100% DP4+ probability (all data) ( Fig. 7 ). Finally, the absolute configuration of 7 was established as (14 R , 16 S , 19 S , 20 S , 21 S ) based on comparison of the experimental and calculated ECD spectra ( Fig. 4 ). Compound 7 is thus identified as 18,19( S )-dihydroxycoronaridine.

Polyneurine H ( 8 )
was obtained as a yellowish oil, [α] D 25 30 ( c 0.1, CHCl 3 ). The UV spectrum exhibited absorption maxima indicative of a hydroxyindolenine chromophore at 223, 232 sh, 266, and 292 nm , while the IR spectrum showed the presence of OH and ester carbonyl groups at 3301 and
1732 cm
1 , respectively. The HRESIMS data ([M + H] + m/z 371.1962) established the molecular formula of 8 as C 21 H 26 N 2 O 4 . The 1 H and 13 C NMR data ( Tables 1 and 2 ) revealed the presence of four aromatic resonances of an unsubstituted indole moiety ( δ H 7.25–7.48), a methyl ester group ( δ H 3.71; δ C 53.4, 172.9), a hydroxyethyl side chain ( δ H 1.24, 3.85; δ C 22.2, 70.3), and a broad singlet at δ H 3.26 due to an OH group (confirmed by D 2 O exchange experiment). The imine function in 8 was readily identified from the characteristic C-2 resonance observed at δ C 188.6, in
addition to the absence of an indolic NH signal in the 1 H NMR spectrum
.
The oxygenated tertiary carbon (C-7) associated with the hydroxyindolenine was clearly observed at δ C 88.0. Examination of the COSY and HMBC data ( Fig. 2 ) led to the structure as shown in 8 . A search of the literature revealed that this 2D structure was previously assigned to heyneanine hydroxyindolenine ( 21 ) ( Sharma and Cordell, 1988 ; Z`eches-Hanrot et al., 1995 ), which does not have identical NMR data to those of 8 , suggesting 8 to be a diastereomer of 21 . Since the relative configurations at C-14, C-16, C-20, and C-21 were established to be the same as those of compounds 1–7 ( Fig. 3 ), the stereochemical differences between compounds 8 and 21 must be at C-7 and/or C-19. As with compounds 3 , 4 , and 7 , the C-19 configuration of 8 was readily determined as R from the observed carbon shifts of C-15 ( δ C 28.5) and C-21 ( δ C 54.2), which correspond to those of the 19 R -hydroxyiboga alkaloid series ( vide supra ) such as 19- epi -heyneanine (C-15 at ca. δ C 29 and C-21 at ca. δ C 55) ( Takayama et al., 1994 ; Wenkert et al., 1976 ). The 19 R configuration was also supported by the GIAO NMR calculations and DP4+ analysis of 8 , which showed 100% probability (all data) ( Fig. 7 ). The configuration at C-7 was assigned as S based on the NOE interaction observed between H-21 and 7-OH ( Fig. 3 ). Finally, the absolute configuration of 8 was established as (7 S , 14 R , 16 S , 19 R , 20 S , 21 S ) based on comparison of the experimental and calculated ECD spectra ( Fig. 4 ). Compound 8 is therefore the 7 S , 19 R diastereomer of 7 R , 19 S -heyneanine hydroxyindolenine
(
21
).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 4. Experimental and calculated ECD spectra of 1 , 3 , 4 , 5 , 7 , and 8 .

subSection.paragraph: Compounds 1 , 2 , 6 , 7 , and 8 were tested for their cytotoxic effect against several human cancer cell lines (HT-29, HCT 116, MCF7, MDA-MB-231, A549, and PC-3) but were found to be inactive (IC 50 > 10 μM).

The present study on the bark of
Tabernaemontana polyneura
afforded eight previously undescribed iboga alkaloids ( 1–8 ). The structures of these compounds were established by interpretation of the MS and NMR data, GIAO NMR calculations and DP4+ probability analysis, TDDFT-ECD method, or X-ray diffraction analysis. A previous study of the same plant from a different location found only four new alkaloids in the stem bark extract, viz., two vobasine and two iboga alkaloids ( Clivio et al., 1990 ). The present study has resulted in the isolation of eight additional previously undescribed iboga alkaloids.

Melting points were determined on an Electrothermal IA9100 digital melting point apparatus and are uncorrected. Optical rotations were measured on a JASCO P-1020 automatic digital polarimeter. UV spectra were obtained on a Shimadzu UV-2600 spectrophotometer. IR spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer RX1 FT-IR spectrophotometer or Spectrum 400 FT-IR/FT-FIR spectrophotometer. HRDART-MS was recorded on a JEOL Accu TOF-DART mass spectrometer, and HRESIMS were obtained on an Agilent LC HR QTOF System Model G6530A or Agilent Technologies 6550 iFunnel Q-TOF LC/MS. 1D and 2D NMR spectra were recorded in CDCl 3 using tetramethylsilane as internal standard on JEOL JNM (ECA 400 MHz) or Bruker Avance III (600 MHz) spectrometers and using a 1.7 mm microprobe for compound 5 . ECD spectra were obtained using JASCO J-810 or JASCO J-815 circular dichroism spectrometers.

Bark of
Tabernaemontana polyneura (King & Gamble) D.J.Middleton (Apocynaceae)
was collected in
June 2016
from Fraser’ s Hill , Pahang , Malaysia (
3.7249 ◦ N
,
101.7143 ◦ E
), and was identified by Dr. K. T. Yong (Institute of Biological Sciences, Universiti Malaya, Malaysia). A voucher specimen ( KLU49438 ) was deposited at the Herbarium, Universiti Malaya
.

Extraction of alkaloids from the ground bark material ( 11.9 kg ) was carried out exhaustively with MeOH at room temperature to afford a viscous extract which was then acidified with 3% tartaric acid. Removal of non-alkaloidal material followed by basification with sodium carbonate and extraction with chloroform gave the crude alkaloidal mixture ( 60 g ). The crude mixture was fractionated by column chromatography (SiO 2 , hexanes/ CH 2 Cl 2 ; MeOH/ CH 2 Cl 2 ) to furnish eleven main fractions (F1–F11). Fraction F2 was rechromatographed (SiO 2 , petroleum ether/EtOAc; MeOH/EtOAc) to give six subfractions (F2a F2f). Repeated purification of the subfraction F2c using preparative radial chromatography (Chromatotron) on SiO 2 yielded compound 1 . Rechromatography of fraction F3 over SiO 2 (petroleum ether/CHCl 3 ; MeOH/CHCl 3 ) gave seven subfractions (F3a F 3g ). Compounds 5 and 8 were obtained from the subfractions F3b and F3c, respectively, by repeated preparative radial chromatography. Further fractionation of fraction F5 by column chromatography (SiO 2 , petroleum ether/EtOAc; MeOH/EtOAc) yielded ten subfractions (F5a F5j). Subfraction F 5g was further purified by repeated preparative radial chromatography to furnish compound 4 . Column chromatography of F6 (SiO 2 , petroleum ether/EtOAc; MeOH/EtOAc) gave 10 subfractions (F6a F6j). Compounds 6 and 7 were isolated from the subfractions F 6g and F6f, respectively, by repeated preparative radial chromatography over SiO 2 . Gel permeation chromatography (Sephadex LH-20, MeOH) of fraction 7 yielded ten subfractions (F7a F7j). The combined subfraction F7c e was subjected to repetitive preparative radial chromatography to yield compound 2 and 3 . The solvent systems used for preparative radial chromatography were MeOH/Et 2 O, petroleum ether/Et 2 O, MeOH/ CHCl 3 , petroleum ether/CHCl 3 , MeOH/ CH 2 Cl 2 , petroleum ether/ CH 2 Cl 2 , CH 2 Cl 2 , MeOH/EtOAc, and petroleum ether/EtOAc. All solvent systems used for preparative radial chromatography were NH 3 -saturated. The yields (mg kg 1 ) of the alkaloids from the bark were as follows: 1 (0.37), 2 (0.59), 3 (0.31), 4 (0.14), 5 (0.13), 6 (0.59), 7 (0.77), and 8 (0.20).

heading.emphasis: 4.4.10. X-ray crystallographic analysis of polyneurines B (2) and F (6)

subSection.paragraph: X-ray diffraction analyses were carried out on a Rigaku Oxford (formerly Agilent Technologies) SuperNova Dual diffractometer with Mo K α ( λ = 0.71073 Å) or Cu K α ( λ = 1.54184 Å) radiation at room temperature. Using Olex2, the structures were solved with SHELXT-2018/2 structure solution program using Intrinsic Phasing and refined with SHELXL-2018/3 refinement package using Least Square minimization. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and all hydrogen atoms were placed in idealized positions and refined as riding atoms with the relative isotropic parameters. Crystallographic data for 2 and 6 had been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. Copies of the data can be obtained, free of charge, on application to the Director, CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK (fax: +44 (0)1223–336033, or e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

Crystallographic Data of 2 . Colorless plates (CCl 4 /MeOH), mp 175–177 ◦ C, C 21 H 28 N 2 O 4 .CCl 4 , M r = 526.26, monoclinic, space group P 21 , a =9.7036 (3) Å, b =9.7698 (3) Å, c =13.5325 (5) Å, β =100.585 (3) ◦ , V =1261.08 (7) Å 3 , Z =2, D calcd = 1.386 g cm 3 , crystal size 0.5 × 0.4 × 0.01 mm 3 , F (000) =548, Mo K α radiation ( λ = 0.71073 Å), T = 293 (2) K. The final R 1 value is 0.0930 (w R 2 = 0.2790) for 6472 reflections [
I > 2
σ(I) ], while the Flack, Hooft, and Parson’ s parameters were x = 0.02 (3), y = 0.05 (2), and z =0.01 (3), respectively. For the inverted structure, the R 1 value is 0.0932 (w R 2 = 0.2796) for 6472 reflections [
I > 2
σ(I) ], while the Flack, Hooft, and Parson’ s parameters were x = 0.98 (3), y = 0.95 (2), and z = 0.99 (3), respectively, from which it follows that the correct enantiomer is the one depicted in Fig. 6 (14 R , 16 S , 19 R , 20 S , 21 S ). CCDC number 2169029.

Crystallographic Data of 6 . Light yellowish block crystals (EtOH), mp 153–154 ◦ C, C 21 H 24 N 2 O 4 .H 2 O, M r =386.44, triclinic, space group P 1, a =7.8152 (6) Å, b =9.4777 (9) Å, c =13.9307 (12) Å, α =77.234 (7) ◦ , β =79.526 (7) ◦ , γ =89.595 (7) ◦ , V =988.98 (15) Å 3 , Z =2, D calcd = 1.298 g cm 3 , crystal size 0.2 × 0.1 × 0.03 mm 3 , F (000) =412, Cu K α radiation ( λ =1.54184 Å), T =293 (2) K. The final R 1 value is 0.0507 (w R 2 = 0.1071) for 7405 reflections [
I > 2
σ(I) ], while the Flack, Hooft, and Parson’ s parameters were x = 0.09 (19), y = 0.10 (18), and z = 0.1 (2), respectively. For the inverted structure, the R 1 value is 0.0508 (w R 2 = 0.1070) for 7405 reflections [
I > 2
σ(I) ], while the Flack, Hooft, and Parson’ s parameters were x =1.08 (19), y =1.10 (18), and z =1.1 (2), respectively, from which it follows that the correct enantiomer is the one depicted in Fig. 9 (14 R , 16 S , 20 R , 21 S ). CCDC number 2169030.
